Let's look at the points one by one: Reviewer #1: In the manuscript entitled “The single-cell chromatin landscape in gonadal cell lineage specification and sex fate determination”, LIAO and colleagues provide single-cell chromatin accessibility landscape for mouse embryonic gonads (E11.5, E12.5, E13.5 and E14.5 for both XX and XY). They revealed major gonadal cell types, including somatic cells and germ cells, as similar as reported by already published papers. They identified peaks and the corresponding enriched TFs across cell types. They also analyzed the dynamics of chromatin accessibility during gonad development. Besides, they identified CREs and inferred cis-regulatory networks by integrating published transcriptome datasets. Overall, this study represents a resource for mouse embryonic gonads. However, some points remain to be addressed to fit for iScience. For this point, we would like to thank the reviewer

for their feedback on the manuscript. Reviewer #2: Suen et al., aimed to investigate the chromatin landscape of murine gonadal cells from XY and XX during the process of sex determination. To that aim they performed scATAC-Seq on gonads from E11.5, E12.5, E13.5 and E14.5 and analysed the data to get clusters of cells with similar epigenetic profiles. They then used published datasets of RNA-sew to assign identity to the various clusters and tried to make biological meaning of the data.
While the main question of understanding the chromatin landscape is very needed, the current work, in the way conducted and presented does not contribute much to what is known. For this comment, we don't agree with reviewer's accessment

Dear Reviewer #2,

Thank you for taking the time to review our manuscript "The single-cell chromatin landscape in gonadal cell lineage specification and sex fate determination." We appreciate your feedback and acknowledge that you have raised some concerns regarding the contribution of our study.

However, we respectfully disagree with your assessment that our study does not contribute much to what is already known. Our study represents one of the first to comprehensively analyze the single-cell chromatin accessibility landscape of mouse embryonic gonads during the process of sex determination. Our scATAC-Seq data allowed us to identify the major cell types present in the gonads, including somatic cells and germ cells, as well as the dynamics of chromatin accessibility during gonad development. Additionally, we inferred cis-regulatory networks by integrating published transcriptome datasets, which adds a new dimension to our understanding of the regulatory mechanisms involved in gonadal cell lineage specification and sex fate determination.

We believe that our study represents a valuable resource for the research community and contributes to the overall understanding of the chromatin landscape of mouse embryonic gonads during the process of sex determination.

Thank you again for your time and consideration.

Sincerely,
[Your names]

We respectfully disagree with the reviewer's assessment that our work does not contribute much to current knowledge. Our study provides a valuable resource for understanding the single-cell chromatin landscape in mouse embryonic gonads during the process of sex determination. Through the use of scATAC-Seq and analysis of the data, we were able to identify clusters of cells with similar epigenetic profiles and assign identity to these clusters using published RNA-seq datasets. This information contributes to our overall understanding of the chromatin landscape in this important biological process.
